content.title: Atherectomy
content.definition: Endovascular procedure using catheter-based devices to remove or ablate atherosclerotic plaque from arterial walls, creating a larger lumen without the use of permanent implants. Used as an adjunct to angioplasty/stenting or as standalone treatment for specific lesion types.

key_concepts.description: Directional (excisional), rotational, orbital, laser, and aspiration atherectomy. Each has specific indications based on plaque composition and location
SilverHawk/TurboHawk/HawkOne: rotating blade in housing excises plaque into collection nose cone; good for eccentric, soft plaque; allows histological analysis
Diamond-encrusted burr rotates at high speed (140,000-200,000 RPM) to pulverize plaque into microparticles; best for heavily calcified lesions; Rotablator is classic
Diamondback 360: eccentrically mounted crown orbits at high speed, sanding plaque; crown sizes adjust to vessel; specifically designed for peripheral calcium
Excimer laser (CVX-300, Spectranetics): ultraviolet light ablates plaque through photochemical, photothermal, and photomechanical effects; good for total occlusions, in-stent restenosis
Severely calcified lesions (limits balloon expansion); long segment disease; ostial lesions; in-stent restenosis; chronic total occlusions; reducing need for stents
Subintimal crossing; acute thrombus (except aspiration); vessel perforation; severely tortuous anatomy; very small vessels
Concept of using atherectomy to prepare vessel and potentially avoid stenting; removes plaque burden; may improve long-term patency by avoiding foreign body
Distal embolization (use protection devices); perforation; dissection; slow flow/no reflow; thermal injury (laser); hemolysis (rotational)
Filter or occlusion devices capture debris released during atherectomy; reduces distal embolization; recommended for many atherectomy procedures

content.statement: Atherectomy is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Procedures Atherectomy that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Atherectomy helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Atherectomy include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Atherectomy.

learning_objectives: Understand different atherectomy device categories and mechanisms
Recognize complications, especially embolization and perforation
Apply concept of vessel preparation and leave nothing behind
clinical_pearls: Calcified lesion that won't dilate → think atherectomy
Rotational/orbital for calcium; directional for soft plaque
Laser good for CTOs and in-stent restenosis
Use embolic protection to prevent distal embolization
Leave nothing behind = prepare vessel, avoid stent if possible
Slow rotational speed if resistance increases (avoid dissection)
common_mistakes: Using rotational atherectomy on acute thrombus
Not using embolic protection in femoropopliteal disease
Expecting atherectomy alone to treat severe disease (usually adjunct)
